title: Physical Activity
text:
Key Statistics







On average, 22.63% of people in US met the physical activity guideline.
Male exercises more compared to female in US as shown in Table 1 and Figure 1.
Working group exercises more compared to non working group in US as shown in Table 2 and Figure 2.







Note



Physical activity guideline can be obtained from here.

title: Exercise Rate in US at state(s) level
section: What about percentage of population in each state which met the Physical Activity Guidelines by Gender ?
text:
What about percentage of population in each state which met the Physical Activity Guidelines by Gender ?
?@fig-stategender further explores the distribution of population in each state which met the Physical Activity Guidelines by Gender. Here, we are showing the 10 states with highest percentage of population who met the guidelines by Male and Female. The results vary slightly compared to the ranking shown in ?@tbl-avgwork . We can observe that among Male, District of Columbia is the most active state, fllowed by Vermont, Idaho and Colorado. As compared to Female, New Hampshire and Colorado share the highest percentage, follow by Utah, Idaho and Washington. However in general, male is generally more active compared to female.






Figure 2: Top 10 States in the United States with the highest percentage of male population who met the physical activity guidelines







Figure 3: Top 10 States in the United States with the highest percentage of female population who met the physical activity guidelines

title: Communicating data with interactive web apps
text:
Use interactivity to enable data exploration, understanding and communication
Design web apps with displays that fit for the purpose
Make web applications using shiny

title: Communicating data with interactive web apps
text:
Analysis

library(tidyverse)
library(tidycovid19)
df <- download_merged_data(cached = TRUE, silent = TRUE)


g <- df %>% 
  filter(country == "Australia") %>% 
  mutate(cases_new = diff(c(0, confirmed))) %>% 
  filter(between(date, as.Date("2022-03-01"), as.Date("2022-08-30"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(date, cases_new)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(x = "Date", y = "New COVID-19 Cases",
       title = "Australia") +
  theme_classic(base_size = 14)

plotly::ggplotly(g)
